option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Before starting the course

First, let's make sure the setup of your environment is ok.

Main method

This method is sometimes added so you can play around with the assignment without having to rely on test output.

Try to execute the main method by pressing on the green arrow to its left.

If the green arrow is not present

There can be various reasons why the green arrow is not showing:

  • you need to install the Kotlin plugin. If you do not know how, ask an instructor (or the person next to you).
But, if the Kotlin plugin is already present, then there is a high likely hood of there being a gradle issue.
  • Open the gradle tool window on the right
  • first press 'refresh'
  • if that goes well, then 'execute gradle task' > popup window > type 'clean build'
There will probably be an error message in one of the steps, which could help you on your way.

Check task - step one

This is used to validate your assignment. It will kick off various Tests and inform you about the result.

Click on the box-checkmark icon in the top of this Task Description. It should try to kick off the tests. However, in this case it should return Compilation failure!

Check task - placeholder

Some assignments have placeholders, which indicate what to fill in where in the task.

To make the currentcheck work, you have to fill in the placeholder in the task. Type "TestMe" (without the quotes) in the placeholder, and run the 'check task' again.

When running "check task", it should now report Congratulations!. This means the placeholder was filled in correctly.

Before you can continue!

Before you can continue, check the hint below. It will tell you something important...
You may now continue ... ;-)

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Hello!

Hello to the world of Kotlin!

To get started we will describe a bit about functions.

Functions are declared using the fun keyword. Functions that are defined inside a class or object are called member functions. Values are returned using the return keyword. 


    fun myFunction():String{
        return "Cowabunga"
    }

This a function returning a String, as defined by the :String after its name

If a function body contains only a single expression, you reduce it to a single-line function.


    fun myFunction() = "Cowabunga"

Function parameters are provided between the "()". They always have the pattern name:Type 


    fun myFunction(myParameter:Int):String{
        return "Cowabunga nr" + myParameter
    }

To call a function just call its name and pass the arguments between the (). 


    myFunction(12)

Assignment

Take a look at function syntax.

Have the function here return the string "Hello " + name.

option.name: name
option.value: Hello, World!

option.name: stepikChangeStatus
option.value: Up to date
"Hello " + name

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Variables

Kotlin has two type of keywords to define variable declarations:
  • val - can only be assigned once
  • var - can be re-assigned

Syntax

Example of declaring a variable: 


    var myVariable:Int = 123

As you can see, the type of the variable is after the variable name, seperated by a colon (:).

Types can be inferred, so the following is allowed as well:


    var myVariable = 123

Kotlin will infer that myVariable is of type Int

Variables can be declared inside functions, as well as outside. The latter called 'top-level' variables.

For more about this topic, read this Kotlin reference.

Assignment

In this task the class MyTask will be instantiated a maxNumberOfTasks times. At each instantiation printTask will be invoked.

All you need to do to make this work is to make sure of the following

  • maxNumberOfTasks is read only
  • numberOfTasks can be reassigned a new value

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
String templating and Raw String

Kotlin has support for Raw Strings and String Literals.

Raw Strings provide you the ability to use newline and spacing without escaping. A raw string is delimited by""" (triple quote) Eg.: 


    var myRawString = """first line
     second line
     third line"""

resulting in 


first line
     second line
     third line

String Templates is the ability to use variables directly in a String. Eg.: 


    var myVar = 123
    println("The value of myVar: $myVar")

resulting in 


The value of myVar: 123

For more complex expressions in the template, you can use ${ ... } (with accolades).

Assignment

Rewrite the below code using raw string and string templates

    
class LittlePony(private val name: String, private val color: String) {

    override fun toString(): String {
        return "\"Name\" : " + name + "\n" + "\"Color\" : " + color
    }
}

Note: \n is the classic sequence for a newline, and \" is used to be able to print a '"'

Read the section about Strings & trimMargin.

option.name: stepikChangeStatus
option.value: Info and Content changed
Trim leading whitespace characters with `trimMargin()`.

option.name: placeholderText

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Other Basic Types

Besides the String, there are of course plenty other basic types. We will quickly go over them.

Characters

A single character. Defined using single quotes (').

Example of the declaration of a character:


    val myChar = 'A'

Booleans

A boolean has two value, true or false. Supported operators are:

  • && : and
  • || : or
  • ! : not

    val myTruth = true || false

Numbers

Kotlin recognizes the following Number types:

  • Double
  • Float
  • Long
  • Int
  • Short
  • Byte

You will most likely recognize all of these.

Example of the declaration of a long:


    val myLong:Long= 123

Arrays

A container of certain objects that has a fixed length. Initialization example: Initialization is done using the arrayOf() function.

You can get an set from/to the array using [i], where i is the index starting from 0.

Example: 


    val myArray = arrayOf(3,2,5,7)
    myArray[2] = myArray[1] + myArray[3] // assign 9 to second index
    // myArray is now [3,2,9,7]

You can read more at Kotlin reference

Assignment

Add all values of the array myArray together and story them in index 0 of myArray

option.name: name
option.value: Other Basic Types

option.value: Info and Content changed

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Class definitions

Classes are defined using the keyword class. An example of a class declaration: 

    class Person(age:Int) {
    }

This is a class Person with a constructor that sets the field age . A class consists of 3 parts:

  • class name - the name of the class
  • class body - the code between the curly braces
  • class header- everything between the class name and body

if the body is empty, the curly braces can be omitted :


    class Person(age:Int)

To have secondary constructors, you define these using the keyword constructor. E.g. 


     class Person(age:Int) {
        constructor(age:Int, name:String) : this(age){
            println("I am the second constructor")
        }
    }

In this example the second constructor delegates to the first constructor, using the this keyword

To instantiate a class, just call it as if it is a regular function, e.g. 


    val john = Person(25, "john")

Assignment

Create a class Car that has two constructors:
  • primary: numberOfWheels (Int) as argument
  • secundary: numberOfWheels and color (String) as arguments

descriptionText
option.value:
Properties

Classes in Kotlin can have properties. These can be declared as mutable, using the var keyword or read-only using the val keyword. 


    class Animal(){
        val nrOfLegs:Int = 0
        var name = "Kermit"
    }

To use a property, you can simply refer it by name: 


    val myAnimal = Animal()
    myAnimal.name = "Dumbo"

For declaring properties and initializing them from the primary constructor, Kotlin has a concise syntax: 


    class Animal(size:Int, val nrOfLegs:Int){
        var name = "Kermit"
    }

In this example, the property 'nrOfLegs' is initialized through the constructor. The 'size' parameter of the constructor however, is not a property.

Almost forgot: everything in Kotlin is public by default! If you do not want to expose something use the private keyword. e.g.

class Animal(size:Int, private val nrOfLegs){ var name = "Kermit" }

Inheritance

To declare an explicit supertype, we place the type after a colon in the class header: 


    open class Animal(size: Int)

    class Dog(size: Int) : Animal(size) //initialize Animal, using size

If the derived class has a primary constructor, the base class should be initialized right there, using the arguments from the constructor.

Every class in Kotlin is final by default. This means they can't be inherited from. To allow other classes to inherit a given class, it should have the keyword open.

Functions

Classes can have functions. Functions in a class are called member functions. They can be accessed the same way as properties.

Overriding functions

To override an inherited function, two things need to be in place

  • it needs to be open in the base class
  • the inheriting class uses the override keyword.

    open class Animal(size: Int){
        open fun eat(){ ... }
    }

    class Dog(size: Int) : Animal(size){
        override fun eat(){ ... }
    }

To read more about classes, read Kotlin reference.

Assignment

Create a class Point that has one constructor parameter, name:String, which initializes a property.
It also has a function 'nrOfCorners' which returns an int of value 0.

Now create a class Line which extends Point, and overrides its function to return 2.

Do the same for Square, but have it return 4

option.value:
Data classes

In Kotlin we can write a Data Transfer Object (DTO) with the usual functionality and utilities that will fit on one line!

This is called a data class and is marked as data:

data class Dto(val id: UUID, val data: String)

The compiler automatically derives the following members from all properties declared in the primary constructor:

  • equals()/hashCode() pair;
  • toString() of the form "Dto(val id: UUID, val data: String)";
  • and more..

Assignment: Write a Person data class

Now we like you to write a data class. Copy the following class. Rewrite it so it becomes a data class 


class Person{

    val name: String
    val age : Int
    val length : Double

    constructor( name : String,  age : Int, length : Double ){
        this.name = name
        this.age = age
        this.length = length
    }

    override fun equals(other: Any?): Boolean {
        if (this === other) return true
        if (javaClass != other?.javaClass) return false

        other as Person

        if (name != other.name) return false
        if (age != other.age) return false
        if (length != other.length) return false

        return true
    }

    override fun hashCode(): Int {
        var result = name.hashCode()
        result = 31 * result + age
        result = 31 * result + length.hashCode()
        return result
    }

}

Like to know more? Read the section about data classes.

descriptionText
option.value:
Import clash

Importing classes with the same name is not allowed in Kotlin. One way we can work around this issue is by omitting the import statement clashing class. Problem with this approach is that the we have refer to the full path of the clashing class when declaring it.


   import some.long.packagename.a.Foobar

   val fooBar : FooBar = FooBar()
   val fooBarB : some.long.packagename.b.FooBar = some.long.packagename.b.FooBar()

Luckily there is a way to import multiple classes with the same name without causing compilation error. In case of ambiguity we can use the keyword as to locally rename the clashing entity:


   import some.long.packagename.a.Foobar
   import some.long.packagename.b.Foobar as FoobarB

   val fooBar : FooBar = FooBar()
   val fooBarB : FoobarB = FooBarB()

Assignment

Add a function named mapToInternalCustomer to the CustomerMapper class. This function will take a domain.external.Customer as a argument and returns a domain.internal.Customer with the same name and id

To improve readability, rename domain.external.Customer to ExternalCustomer by using the as keyword.

For more information, read the section about Imports.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Control Flow

There are several mechanisms for controlling the flow of your application:

  • if
  • when
  • for
  • while

If

Just your classic if statement. Kotlin does not support ternary operators (condition ? then : else). An example: 


    if( someTest() ) {
        println("Test successful")
    } else {
        println("Test failed")
    }

When

The when expression replaces the commonly used 'switch' statement. It looks as following: 


    when (myValue) {
        1 -> print("myValue is 1")
        2 -> print("myValue is 2")
        else -> { // Note the block
            print("myValue is neither")
        }
    }

You can use arbitrary expressions, not just constants, as branch conditions. For example: 


    when (myObject) {
        is Car -> print("myObject is a Car")
        is Plane -> print("myObject is a Plane")
        else -> { // Note the block
            print("myObject is an UFO")
        }
    }

When matches each condition in order and executes the first one that matches. If none match, else is executed.

For

A for loop can range over anything that provides an iterator (collections and such). Example of a for loop: 


    for (someVal in myCollection) {
       println(someVal)
    }

The code block is optional if it contains only one expression.

Ranges

To iterate over a range of numbers, you can use a range expression. E.g. 


    for (i in 1..10) {
       println(i)
    }

This prints 1 to 10 (including 10)

For more about ranges, read this Kotlin reference

While

Another classic. The while loop. Kotlin supports as well while as do ... while


    while( x > 0 ){
        x--
    }


    do {
        y--
    } while (y >0)

Break/Continue

And Kotlin supports the age-old break and continue operators in loops, to either abort the loop, or start the next iteration respectively.

Assignment

Complete the collectGarbage() method so that it counts the Garabage and stores the values in the corresponding fields of the GarbageCollector class. The categorization is as follows

  • recyclable = Plastic and Glass
  • organic = Green
  • burnables = Paper
  • chemicals = Chemicals,Oil and Batteries

Note: List<Garbage> is an iterable over Garbage.

For more information about Control Flow read the Kotlin reference

descriptionText
option.value:
Nullable safety

Kotlin's type system is aimed at eliminating the danger of null references from code, also known as the The Billion Dollar Mistake.

Nullable types

In kotlin the type system distinguishes between references that can hold null (nullable references) and those that can not. It does by adding a question mark(?) to the type

Example: 


    var a: String = "abc"
    a = null // compilation error
    val l = a.length // no problem
To allow nulls, we can declare a variable as nullable string, written String?: 

    var b: String? = "abc"
    b = null // ok
    val l = b.length // ERROR: b could be null

Null checks

If you have a nullable reference, you can't use its properties or methods without checking wether or not the reference is null beforehand. This can be done in various ways.

Classic if-else 
val l = if (b != null) b.length else -1
Safe calls

The second option is the safe call operator, written ?.

b?.length

If b is not null, it will return the value of length, otherwise it will return null.

You can also combine this together with let to have a method only execute if a reference is not null. 


myString?.let { println(it.length) } // prints the length of the string if it exists

You can also use it on the assignment side: only assign something it the reference is not null 

person?.department?.head = "John"
Elvis Operator

Instead of saying 

val l: Int = if (b != null) b.length else -1

You can shorten it to : 

val l = b?.length ?: -1
Not-Null Assertion (!!)

You can force a NullPointerException (NPE) if a reference is null, by using the !! operator 

val x=y!!.length

This will throw a NPE if y is null. Use this very sparingly.

Safe Casts

When using safe casts, the operation will return null if the cast fails: 

val aInt: Int? = a as? Int

Assignment

Rewrite the body of sendMessageToClient() so it will contain only a single if statement.

Read the full manual at kotlin docs

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Platform types

Any reference in Java may be null, which makes Kotlin's requirements of strict null-safety impractical for objects coming from Java. Types of Java declarations are treated specially in Kotlin and called platform types.

A platform type is indicated by IntelliJ with an exlamation mark (!)

When you receive a reference from a java call, you can choose to treat it as a nullable or non-nullable. When you assign the reference to a non-nullable variable, an assertion will take place.

For example: 


    val resultA = someJavaCall() //result is a platform type

    resultA.someMethod() //throws NullPointerException if resultA is null

    val resultB:String = someJavaCall() //will throw IllegalStateException if result is null
    val resultC:String? = someJavaCall() //result is considered a nullable reference

Assignment

Create a wrapper for the Java receiveMail method. Make sure it never returns null, but an empty list at best.

Note: to create an empty list, use listOf()

Read the full manual at kotlin docs

name
option.value: Functions and Lambdas

option.name: stepikChangeStatus
option.value: Up to date

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Functions

Functions in Kotlin are first-class citizens. This means it can be passed as an argument, returned from a function, modified and assigned to a variable.

Functions are declared using the fun keyword. Functions that are defined inside a class or object are called member functions. Values are returned using the return keyword. An example: 

 
        fun add(left: Int, right: Int): Int {
            return left + right
        }
This is a method accepting two parameters, 'left' and 'right', each of the type Int. It also indicates that it will return an Int.

Arguments

Named Arguments

When calling functions, the arguments can be named. e.g, instead of calling

add( 12, 15 )
you can call 
add( left=12, right=15 )
or 
add(  right=15, left=12 )

Default arguments

Default arguments can be defined using the = after the type along with the value. e.g. fun add(left:Int, right:Int = 0 ) will allow you to use the add function without a second argument. If done so, the second argument will have the value 0.

Variable number of arguments

A function can have a variable number of arguments, using the vararg keyword. 


    fun asList(vararg messages:String): List<String> {
    val result = ArrayList<String>()
    for (body in messages) //messages is an Array
        result.add(body)
    return result
}

Inside the function, the vararg parameter is seen as an array.

Note: if a vararg is not the last argument in the list, arguments following it, can be passed by name

Assignment

Create a function add() that takes a variable number of arguments, and adds only those that are even. Subsequently returning the sum.

For the documentation regarding functions see here.

option.name: stepikChangeStatus
option.value: Info and Content changed

option.name: placeholderText

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Lambdas

Lambda expressions are function literals. This means they are not declared, but passed immediately as an expression. An example of a function call with a lambda: 


    max( strings, { a, b -> a.length < b.length } )

In this example, the lambda is the second argument of the max function; the part that says:
{ a, b -> a.length < b.length }
This expression takes two arguments, a and b, which are inferred to be strings, and returns true if b is longer than a.

Syntax

A lambda expression is

  • always surrounded by curly braces,
  • parameter declarations in the full syntactic form go inside curly braces and have optional type annotations,
  • the body goes after an -> sign.
And if the inferred return type of the lambda is not Unit, the last (or possibly single) expression inside the lambda body is treated as the return value.

If your lambda has a single parameter, you can refer to it as it. E.g. 


    { a:String -> it.length }

If a lambda parameter is unused, you can use the _. For example, we can change the first example: 


     max( strings, { _, b -> b.length == 12} )

Note: this would be a terrible max function call.

You can read more about this in the Kotlin reference

Assignment

Same as the previous assignment, however, now use the Array.filter() (See Array kotlin doc) method and pass a lambda to it. It might also be interesting to look at the .forEach() function.

option.name: stepikChangeStatus
option.value: Info and Content changed

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Infix functions

Example of the usage of an infix function looks like this: 


    myDog eats "munchies"

eats is in this example an infix function. It is a member function of myDog and receives one argument "munchies".

An infix function is a function that

  • Is either a member function or extension function
  • Has a single parameter
  • The parameter is not a vararg nor has a default value
(Extension functions will be discussed later on)

To define the infix function above, you would do the following: 


    class Dog{
        infix fun eats(food:String) = println("Eating $food")
    }

By preceding the function with the keyword infix and can be used as an infix function.

An example of an infix function that is already present within Kotlin would be the to function (used for example when creating a Map) :
"a" to 7
This will call a to() method on String to produce a Pair object containing "a" and 7. (This also involves extension functions and generics)

Read more at this Kotlin reference

Assignment

Create a class MyNum that has
  • A Int value passed in its constructor
  • An infix method add accepting an integer, which returns the sum of the class value and the parameter

descriptionText
option.value:
Higher Order Functions

Higher order functions (HOF), is an expensive way of saying

A function that has a function as a parameter

Since functions are first-class citizens in Kotlin, you can pass functions around as parameters.

Just as a regular parameter: to have a function as a parameter, you have to define its type. The type of a function is defined in the following form: 

    (A , B) -> C

This specifies the signature of the expected function. Between parentheses, you specify its parameter types (A and B). After the -> you define its return type (C).

Functions that have no parameters are specified using empty braces, e.g. () -> C.

Functions that have no return value are always specified with the type Unit, e.g. (Int, Int) -> Unit

An example of a function definition of a higher order function: 


    fun theHoff( kittWristwatch: (String)->Boolean ){
        println("Kitt, execute!")
        val isSuccess = kittWristwatch("IncreaseSizeOfShark")

        if( isSuccess ) {
            println("Thanks Kitt!")
        } else {
            println("x⸑x")
        }
    }

So, theHoff is expected a function he calls 'kittWristwatch'. This function should expect a String and should return a Boolean.

A call to theHoff looks as follows 


    val brokenWristwatch:(String) -> Boolean = { command:String ->
        println("Sorry, I can't do that Michael")
        false
    }

    theHoff( brokenWristwatch )

Off course, this can be shortened by applying the lambda directly: 


    theHoff{ command ->
        println("Sorry, I can't do that Michael")
        false
    }

Notice the absence of braces. If the lambda is the only argument to that call, the parentheses can be omitted entirely.

You can read more about Kotlin HOF in the Kotlin reference.

Assignment

Now for the assignment we want you to write a Stopwatch object. The Stopwatch object has a method which will measure the execution time of a given function.

It has the following requirements, it:

  • is named "elapse"
  • will execute the given function. The given function should not expect any parameters nor have any output (=Unit)
  • will return the duration of that function

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Explanation

As in Java, classes in Kotlin may have type parameters:

class Box<T>(t: T) { var value = t }

Here T is the type parameter, indicating what type the argument t has.

In general, to create an instance of such a class, we need to provide the type arguments:

val box: Box<Int> = Box<Int>(1)

This creates a box that will have an Int in the value field.

But if the parameters may be inferred, e.g. from the constructor arguments or by some other means, one is allowed to omit the type arguments:

val box = Box(1) // 1 has type Int, so the compiler figures out that we are talking about Box

You can read more in the Kotlin reference.

Generic functions

Generic types are not only for classes. Functions can have them too: 


    fun <T> doSomething(item: T): List<T>

The function in the example has a generic type T. The generic type is always defined before the function name.

When calling a generic function, you specify the type arguments after the name of the function, e.g.: 


    val myCat = Cat()
    val myCatList = doSomething<Cat>( myCat )

You can read more at Kotlin reference

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
List

A list is not created using a constructor, but through the method listOf(). E.g. 


    val myList = listOf(1,3,4)

However, the standard List in Kotlin is immutable. Which means methods to add and remove elements do not exist. Once the List is created, its objects cannot be added or removed.

To create a mutable list, you use the method mutableListOf(). The result is a List that does have the methods to add and remove elements

Standard operations on a List are as following (note: list indices, start at 0) 


    val myList = mutableListOf("A" , "B" , "C" )
    var item = myList[1]  // get the 2nd item == "B"
    myList.size //returns the number of elements


    //only when mutable
    myList[1] = "X"  //replace the 2nd item, only when mutable
    item = myList[1] // == "X"
    myList.remove("X") // remove "X" from List
    myList.removeAt(0) // remove whatever is at index 0
    myList.clear() //remove all elements

Assignment

There are two methods one receiving a mutable List, the other an immutable List. Both methods should return an immutable list that has the following changes:

  • change the third item to "d"
  • remove the second item
But only perform these actions if the indices are present. But, you say, I can't change an immutable list! You can however create an immutable list from a mutable list, using the toMutableList() method. Bonus questions:
  • When creating a mutable list using toMutableList, do operations on the new list, influence the old?
  • If the mutable list is assigned to a val, can you still add/remove items?


For a complete list of all List methods: Kotlin doc And a Kotlin intro on Collections: Kotlin reference

option.value:
import org.junit.Assert.assertEquals import org.junit.Test
class Test { @Test fun testSolution() { assertEquals( """Mistake in handling immutableList, with input : "a", "b", "c", "d"""", listOf("a","d","d"), handleImmutableList(listOf( "a", "b", "c", "d")) )
assertEquals( """Mistake in handling immutableList, with input : "a"""", listOf("a"), handleImmutableList(listOf( "a")) )
assertEquals( """Mistake in handling immutableList, with input : "a", "b"""", listOf("a"), handleImmutableList(listOf( "a", "b")) )
assertEquals( """Mistake in handling immutableList, with input : "a", "b","c"""", listOf("a", "d"), handleImmutableList(listOf( "a", "b", "c")) )
assertEquals( """Mistake in handling mutableList, with input : "a", "b","c","d"""", listOf("a","d","d"), handleMutableList(mutableListOf( "a", "b", "c", "d")) )
assertEquals( """Mistake in handling mutableList, with input : "a"""", listOf("a"), handleMutableList(mutableListOf( "a")) )
assertEquals( """Mistake in handling mutableList, with input : "a", "b"""", listOf("a"), handleMutableList(mutableListOf( "a", "b")) )
assertEquals( """Mistake in handling mutableList, with input : "a", "b","c"""", listOf("a", "d"), handleMutableList(mutableListOf( "a", "b", "c")) ) } }

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Maps

Just as List, a Map is a type of collection that can be mutable or immutable. This collection holds pairs of objects (keys and values). Instantiation is done through the methods mapOf() and mutableMapOf(). 


    //pretty idiom for creating a map
    val myMap = mutableMapOf("a" to "apple", "b" to "bee")

    //less pretty, more efficient
    val myOtherMap = mutableMapOf(
            Pair("a", "apple"),
            Pair("b", "bee")
    )

    println(myMap["a"])

    myMap["a"] = "Adam"
    myMap["z"] = "zoolander"
    myMap.remove("b")

Assignment

We will more or less do the something that we did for List, but now for Map:

There are two methods one receiving a mutable Map, the other an immutable Map. Both methods should return an immutable Map that has the following changes:

  • change the value for item with key "x" to 345
  • remove the item with key "z"

For a complete list of all Map methods: Kotlin doc

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Extension Functions To declare an extension function, we need to prefix its name with a receiver type, i.e. the type being extended. The following adds a prefix function to String:

fun String.prefix() = "prefix> $this"

The this keyword inside an extension function corresponds to the receiver object (the one that is passed before the dot). Now, we can call such a function on any String:

"my great string".prefix()

and this will return 

prefix> my great string

Assignment

Create a hello() extension function for String that will return "hello xyz", where "xyz" was the original string.

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Object Declarations


When we need to implement an interface without explicitly declaring a new implementation class or we want to declare a singleton object, in Kotlin we can do this by simply declaring an object.

An object declaration looks like this :

    
        object Utility{
            fun formatter(){
                ...
            }
        }

Or with a supertype : 

    
        object Utility : BaseUtilities{
            fun formatter(){
                ...
            }
        }

Couple of things to note :

  • it always has a name following the object keyword
  • an object declaration cannot be local (i.e. be nested directly inside a function).

You can read more about object declarations in the Kotlin reference.

Assignment

Declare the following in Task.kt:

  • a singleton object named Counter. You can declare an object by using Intellij's auto completion. While typing 'singleton' press the return key
  • a private Int variable count with initial value 0.
  • a function countUp that increments count and returns the incremented value.

descriptionText

Object expressions


Object expressions can come in handy when we want to create an object of a slight modification of some class, without explicitly declaring a new subclass for it. This we call creating an object of anonymous class.

Here we have an example of an object expression:


open class A{
    open fun someFun(){
        println("hello")
    }

}

fun foo() {
    val adHoc = object : A(){
        override fun someFun(){
            println("is it me you're looking for?")
        }
    }
 }

Code in object expressions can access properties from the enclosing scope:




interface B{
    fun counter()
}

class FooBar() {

    var count = 0

    val adHoc = object : B{
        override fun counter(){
            count++
        }
    }
 }

You can read more about Object Expressions at: Kotlin reference.

A PrintShopOwner has a printedDocument property and a printIt function.
In order to print something, a PrintShopOwner will have to call the printDocument function from the PrintShop.

Objective:

  • create an object from the Printer interface and pass it into the printDocument method.
  • override the print method
  • assign document to printedDocument variable.

Companion Object

Object declaration inside a class can be marked with the companion keyword.

The nice thing about a Companion object is that the functions or values declared inside it will look like they are part of the class it accompanies.

    
      class SomeClass {

        companion object CompanionObject {
            fun doSomething(){
                println("something")
            }
        }
      }
      val x = SomeClass.doSomething()
      val actualCompanionObject = SomeClass.CompanionObject

We don't even have to name the companion object:

    
      class SomeClass {
        companion object {
            fun doSomething(){
                println("something")
            }
        }
      }
      val x = SomeClass.doSomething()
      val actualCompanionObject = SomeClass.Companion

Assignment

One use case of a companion object could be an implementation of the factory pattern.

The factory’s goal is to deliver a ready-to-use object to its client. The factory hides the complexity of creating and selecting the right object for the job.

Now it's time for you to create a companion object.

You know exactly what a plumbus is and how it’s used. Now we will create a PlumbusFactory! The factory will create simple Plumbuses, assign each one an id, and count how many have been made.

There currently is a Plumbus class with a private constructor (so no one create his own home-grown Plumbus). It is your job to add a companion object by the name PlumbusFactory. This factory has two things:

  1. A count property indicating how many Plumbuses have been created.
  2. A create() function, which increments the count and returns a fresh Plumbus with an id that is equivalent to the new count/

To get an idea what it will look like when used: see the commented out code in the main method.

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Unit testing

Let's turn things around! We have some code we need to cover with our tests.

The common structure of a test file looks like this: 

    
class Test {

    @Before
    fun setup() {
        // Everything you like to do before each test has run
    }

    @After
    fun teardown() {
          // Everything you like to do after each test has run
    }

    @Test
    fun a_should_be_equal_to_a() {
        val expected = "a"
        val actual = "a"

        assertEquals(expected, actual, "Should return equal")
    }

}

Each line of code we call from an annotated with @Test method will effect the code coverage. The higher your code coverage is the smaller the chance that you will find unexpected behaviour in your application. Highly tested code base makes easier to maintain or to refactor the code base.

Complete the unit tests and view the code coverage. Aim at 100 percent code coverage.

See this page on viewing code coverage report in Intellij.

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Variance

Variance refers to how subtyping between generics relates to the actual type parameters.

We will describe three types of variances, what they are and what use they have.

Invariance

When you create a generic class, it will by default be considered invariant.

What does this mean?

It means that when you have the following code: 

    interface Animal

    class Dog:Animal

    class Carrier<T>( var thing: T)

Then, even though do Dog implements Animal, you can't do the following: 

    val dogCarrier : Carrier<Dog> = Carrier(Dog())
    val animalCarrier : Carrier<Animal> = dogCarrier

Why would they not allow this (by default)?

Let's assume we can assign it, then the following would be possible: 

    val dogCarrier : Carrier<Dog> = Carrier(Dog())
    //assume this is possible for the example
    val animalCarrier : Carrier<Animal> = dogCarrier

    //now we can do this:
    animalCarrier.thing = Horse()  //With Horse also implementing Animal

So we could put a Horse in our dogCarrier ! That is definitely unwanted

Assignment

Fix the assignment of the DogCarrier to befit an invariant. i.e. not an animalcarrier.

option.name: name
option.value: Variance - invariant

option.name: stepikChangeStatus
option.value: Up to date

option.name: placeholderText
possibleAnswer
option.value: var myCarrier: Carrier<Dog> = dogCarrier

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Covariance

What does this mean

Covariance means that the following is possible: 
    val dogCarrier : Carrier<Dog> = Carrier(Dog())
    val animalCarrier : Carrier<Animal> = dogCarrier
In other words: the ordering of the generic follows the ordering of the generic type. When Dog extends Animal, Carrier<Dog> can be considered to extend Carrier<Animal>.

Why would we want this?

Let's say you have a class Carrier<T>: and it has only methods that return T, and there are no methods that have T as their arguments. In this case covariance would be desired, because there would be no possibility, as by our example, to provide an Animal to a dogCarrier.

For example: 

    class Carrier<T>(private val thing: T){
        fun getThing():T = thing
    }


    val dogCarrier : Carrier<Dog> = Carrier(Dog())
    val animalCarrier: Carrier<Animal> = dogCarrier

    val animal:Animal = animalCarrier.getThing()  //not a problem
    // and there are no methods in Carrier with argument T

If you have a class as described above, with only methods returning T and no methods with T as argument, we call this a producer.

How to make a class covariant?

Making a class covariant, in other words, having Carrier<Dog> to be considered extending Carrier<Animal>, requires you to add the keyword out 
    class Carrier<out T>(private val thing: T){
        fun getThing():T = thing
    }
If you don't add out, kotlin will keep considering the class invariant. Be aware however that you can only add out to classes that have NO methods with T as argument !

Assignment

The current class is not covariant. Make it so that it can and will be covariant:
  • Make the class a producer: remove all consumer methods
  • Add the right keyword
  • And eventually assign a dog carrier to an animal carrier

option.name: name
option.value: Variance - covariance

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Contravariance

What does this mean

Contravariance means that the following is possible: 
    class Dog
    class DanishDog:Dog

    val dogTrainer : Trainer<Dog> = Trainer<Dog>()
    val danishDogTrainer : Trainer<DanishDog> = dogTrainer
In other words: the ordering of the generic is contra to the ordering of the generic type. When DanishDog extends Dog, Trainer<Dog> can be considered to extend Trainer<DanishDog>.

Why would we want this?

Let's say you have a class Trainer<T>: and it has only methods that consume T, and there are no methods that return T. In this case contravariance could be desired, because the methods that consume the superclass, will have no problem consuming the subclass.

For example: 

    abstract class Dog(val name:String)
    class DanishDog(name:String):Dog(name)

    interface Trainer<T>{
        fun train(target:T)
    }

    val dogTrainer = object:Trainer<Dog>{
        override fun train(target:Dog) {
            println("Dog ${target.name} is trained")
        }
    }

    val danishDogTrainer:Trainer<DanishDog> = dogTrainer

In this example it shoukd not be a problem to cast the dogTrainer to the danishDogTrainer. This is because it has only methods consuming T, and when such a method process Dog, it has no problem processing a DanishDog.

If you have a class as described above, with only methods that have T as an argument and no methods returning T, we call this a consumer.

How to make a class contravariant?

Making a class contravariant, in other words, having Trainer<Dog> to be considered extending Trainer<DanishDog>, requires you to add the keyword in 
    class Trainer<in T>{
        fun train(target:T)
    }
If you don't add in, kotlin will keep considering the class invariant. Be aware however that you can only add in to classes that have NO methods that return T!

Assignment

The current class is not contravariant. Make it so that it can and will be contravariant:
  • Make the class a consumer: remove all producer methods
  • Add the right keyword
  • Eventually assign a generic dog trainer to a danish dog trainer to showcase the contravariance

option.name: name
option.value: Variance - contravariance
